item.title: About
item.description: Welcome to my personal site! I’m currently an AI Researcher at JHUAPL. I’ve had an unusual path into AI research. Toward the end of my sophomore year at Northwestern University, injuries brought my football career to an early conclusion. I turned my attention to neuroscience, and after falling in love with the subject, I contemplated both the pursuit of a Ph.D. in neuroscience, and medical school, at different points throughout my senior year.

item.title: Athletics
item.description: Having played football for 16 years and having been a full scholarship athlete at Northwestern, I’m often met with surprise when people find out I don’t watch or follow any sports. So, although I can definitely talk about sports generally, if you were to ask me something specific about a player or team, it is likely I will not have the answer. However, I do enjoy being an athlete. For fun, here is my high school highlight tape:

item.title: Music
item.description: During my freshman year at Northwestern (2013), I became interested in digital music production. I purchased a MIDI device, the M-Audio Keystation Mini 32, because it was the cheapest and smallest one I could find, and it came with a simple software called Ignite, which I used to make loops. I was gifted a copy of Sony ACID Music studio (a Digital Audio Workstation) and developed a process where after creating instrumental loops in Ignite, I would open them in ACID to polish them into a full piece.

item.title: Photography
item.description: I’ve been fascinated with photography since I was a kid.* Luckily for me, my high school had a TV Studio extracurricular that gave me the opportunity to spend a lot of time using DSLRs, shoulder-mount video cameras and a few different professional photo and video editing softwares, so I was able to get a reasonable amount of practice fairly early on. Now I mainly use a DJI Mavic Air 2, a Sony Cybershot that is a few years old but still great, and I have a Rylo (r.

item.title: Projects
item.description: I’ve written a lot of code and enjoy writing code, so that volume is growing. That being said, I’m relatively selective about what I keep in a public repository. Here are a couple of projects that I’ve worked on with links to what is available. I will update this page as I make more code available on GitHub. Grand Canyon Traffic Detection This project originated from a quick drive I wanted to take up to the Grand Canyon.

item.title: Reading List
item.description: I read a lot. (A more extensive list can be found here) It’s usually nonfiction but I’ve included some of my favorite novels too. Here is a short list containing eight of my favorites I’d be willing to risk my recommendation reputation on. Previously, I’d linked all of the titles to their page on Goodreads, but I despise how cluttered the site is and have since discovered StoryGraph; it’s an up-and-coming competitor which supports Bookshop.
